placeMetadata.description: Majestic Neo-Gothic cathedral known for its airy sanctuary, stained glass & soaring twin spires.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: St. Philomena's Cathedral, located in Mysore, is a stunning neo-gothic church with soaring twin spires and intricate stained glass windows depicting the Christ era. Built between 1933-1941, it was inspired by the Cologne Cathedral in Germany. The church houses a relic of Saint Philomena obtained in 1926 and features a candlelit prayer room that offers solace to visitors.
placeMetadata.address: 3042/1, Sawday Rd, near St. Chnilomina Church, Lashkar Mohalla, Lourdu Nagar, Mandi Mohalla, Mysuru, Karnataka 570001, India

reviews.reviewText:
A Majestic Masterpiece of Faith and Architecture

St. Philomena's Cathedral is absolutely breathtaking. From the moment you step onto the grounds, you're greeted with towering spires and stunning neo-gothic architecture that rivals some of the finest cathedrals in Europe. The stained glass windows, especially the ones depicting scenes from the life of Christ, are nothing short of mesmerizing when sunlight streams through them.

Inside, the atmosphere is peaceful and reverent‚Äîperfect for prayer, reflection, or simply soaking in the beauty. The craftsmanship in every detail, from the altars to the ceiling arches, shows deep devotion and incredible artistry.

Whether you're religious or simply a lover of history and architecture, this cathedral is a must-visit. A true gem of Mysuru that leaves a lasting impression.

---

Want a shorter version or one with a more personal tone?

A peaceful and beautiful church with stunning architecture. The calm atmosphere makes it perfect for prayer and reflection. The stained glass windows and intricate design add to its charm. A must-visit for anyone seeking serenity and history in one place.

This beautiful Cathedral was built in 1956 and is one of the largest churches in the country. It has been built in the Gothic style with beautiful stain glass windows and lofty towers. The illuminated church in the evening is a wonderful site not to be missed.

The church's Gothic-style architecture, with its towering spires, stunning stained-glass windows, and intricate carvings, is a sight to behold. The serene atmosphere and peaceful ambiance make it an ideal spot for prayer, reflection, and contemplation.

The moment you step inside, the high ceilings and beautifully crafted interiors transport you to a different era. The altar, the sculptures, and the detailed carvings showcase the craftsmanship that went into building this historical church. The stained-glass windows depicting scenes from Christ‚Äôs life add to the spiritual charm.

It‚Äôs close to mysore palace 2.5km away and adjacent to muslim moholla. Absolute beauty to visit with friends or family and a must not place to miss during your next trip to Mysore.

St. Philomena‚Äôs Church in Mysore stands as one of the most remarkable examples of Neo-Gothic architecture in India. Built in 1936, its soaring twin spires, visible from afar, make it an iconic landmark of the city. The church interior is equally captivating, with impressive stained-glass panels depicting scenes from the life of Christ, creating a serene and contemplative atmosphere.

The church premises are well maintained, offering visitors both a spiritual retreat and a glimpse into Mysore‚Äôs rich heritage. It is not only a place of worship but also a cultural attraction that draws people from around the world. For anyone exploring Mysore, St. Philomena‚Äôs Church is an essential stop that beautifully blends history, architecture, and devotion.

What a beautiful architecture this building has! it is really pretty and they allow tourists also to take photos and videos. The prayers happen every two hours but outside it's always open. Good view, a must visit if in Mysore.

St. Philomena‚Äôs Church in Mysore is truly breathtaking. From the outside, its majestic neo-Gothic architecture rises proudly toward the sky, leaving visitors in awe. What I found especially fascinating is that the church looks much larger from the outside than it feels on the inside ‚Äì the interior seems almost small and humble in comparison, yet this adds to its charm and intimacy. The church is spotless, well maintained, and offers a peaceful space for rest, reflection, and prayer. A visit to Mysore would not be complete without experiencing this beautiful and imposing landmark.
A great architectural brilliance can be seen. What a massive structure with such good atmosphere. People, the ambience, you will feel yeah a holy place to keep our heart at.

St. Philomena's Cathedral is a Catholic church of Mysore Diocese of India, located Ashok road near Mysore Palace. It was constructed in 1936 with a Neo Gothic style, honour to the memory of Saint Philomena. It's architecture was inspired by the beautiful Cologne Cathedral in Germany. It is one of the tallest church in Asia. The twins spires raising 175 feet are inspiring and the stained glass windows, lofty towers and a marble altar. The outside of the church looks grand, and inside feel spiritual. The serene interior offers a peaceful atmosphere for reflections. It welcomes visitors of all religion and the most important thing is you need to maintain silence. The church is open from 5 am to 6 pm and you can attend mass at the church, which held in Kannada, Tamil and English. It's a very divine place just stand inside the prayer hall, and feel the waves of peace flowing in to your soul.

The parking is quite difficult.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Mysore Zoo Park is a popular weekend destination, offering a well-maintained animal kingdom that allows visitors to connect with nature. The zoo provides ample space and greenery, with amenities such as RO water stations and resting areas along the 3km walking path. Families can enjoy seeing a variety of wild animals in a clean and well-maintained environment, making it an outstanding place for leisurely visits. Additionally, the park's surroundings offer a rejuvenating experience for all visitors.
placeMetadata.address: Sri Chamarajendra Zoological Gardens, Zoo Rd, Indiranagar, Mysuru, Karnataka 570010, India

reviews.reviewText: It is one of the best zoos of the country.Sri Chamarajendra Zoological Gardens, popularly known as ‚ÄòMysuru Zoo‚Äô, is one of the oldest zoos of the country established in 1892, by His Highness, the erstwhile Ruler of Mysuru Sri Chamarajendra Wadiyar Bahadur. Mysuru Zoo holds an important place in Karnataka. In 1909 the Palace Zoo was named as Sri Chamarajendra Zoological Gardens to commemorate the illustrious founder and since then it bears the nomenclature. Mysuru Zoo has gradually grown into tourist centre, imparting wildlife values. It has got 123 years of history exhibiting wild animals in the near natural enclosures. Despite majority of the zoos have been shifted from the original place to the new places, Mysuru Zoo could modernize the zoo, without shifting the zoo. The zoo is well compacted unit, with modern animal enclosures including heritage buildings attracting tourists all over the world.Great place to visit with kids above 5 years, they really appreciate the variety of birds, animals and reptiles. It took us 4 hours to complete the walk around the entire Zoo, which included a 30 min break at the cafeteria, just to rest. The food at the cafeteria is primarily south Indian food, which didn't intrigue us much, since we were eating the same for the last couple of days. Make sure you wear the most comfortable shoes if you plan to walk, and carry a bottle, so you can fill it up at the watering stations, which are well spaced out, carry a cap, it's not too hot though cause of all the trees. There is also a buggy option, however they cover the entire Zoo in an hour and you don't get time to spend at each exhibit, it's a quick tour. The zoo doesn't permit plastics, or outside food, they check the bags at the entrance post buying your tickets.

Mysore Zoo is a wonderful place for animal lovers and those interested in studying wildlife. The zoo is clean, well-maintained, and thoughtfully organized with separate sections for birds, reptiles, wild animals, and more. Visitors can explore the zoo on foot, covering approximately 3 kilometers, or opt for electric buggies for convenience. I will recommend it by foot if you can make it, so you can manage where to spend time. The entry fee is ‚Çπ100 per person. The lush greenery throughout the zoo provides a soothing and refreshing atmosphere. The walkways are beautifully designed, making the visit even more enjoyable.  It's a must-visit destination, especially for families with kids, offering a unique and memorable experience to spend quality time together.

Mysore zoo was a wonderful place for the people who love animals and who study about the wildlife. The zoo was clean and well maintained. There are separate areas for birds , reptiles, wild animals etc. Around 2 km we need to walk to see the zoo. There are ev buggies available in the zoo . There is an entry fee of 100 per person. Some areas of the zoo need to improve. In the zoo there is really good greenery which cools our eyes. The walkway of the zoo was beautiful.

Really loved the zoo. Very nicely maintained, clean and you see so many wild life. Weekends can be crowded. No food allowed inside the zoo but they have filtered water taps inside. restrooms are there however they are not clean and I dont blame the staff completely, I saw them cleaning but people have hard time maintaining cleanliness in public space in our country. But overall you will have a fun family time, especially kids are going to love to see the animals.

For kids and animal lovers, it is worth visiting to see and experience the live animals. It has a restaurant, snacks and souvenir shop as well. My favorite is giraffe ü¶í awesome to watch them üòä a bit crowded during weekend!
Few animals were not there. And I had alot issue getting parking I had to par my car about 1km away and had to walk there. Best part was we could book the tickets via whatsapp.

The zoo had completed 100 years in 1992. The centenary celebrations were held in 1990 and 91. During the centenary celebrations various developmental activities were initiated such as renovation and modification of the entrance gate, hospital building, walkthrough reptiles, etc. A bust of Chamaraja Wadiyar X was unveiled. The logo of the zoo, centenary souvenir, publication of literature and leaflets, conducting various competitions, preparation of a documentary film were other highlights..
Rescue and rehabilitation of the wild animals and birds stay in this Zoo ...
Really maintain clean and Green , Thank you so much for staff and Management team ...

A must visit place in Mysore. If anyone plans to visit here should be spending atleast 3-4hrs minimum to enjoy watching these amazing creatures.
The Gorillas, African elephants, lions, Rhinos, Wolves and so many more

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Mysore Palace, a stunning Indo-Saracenic architectural marvel completed in 1912, boasts a grand durbar hall and hosts weekly illuminations. The palace is famous for the traditional Dasara procession, Jamboo Savari, featuring a decorated elephant carrying the idol of Goddess Chamundeshwari during Vijaya Dashami. This centuries-old celebration was initiated by Raja Wodeyar in 1610 and has continued uninterrupted.
placeMetadata.address: Agrahara, Chamrajpura, Mysuru, Karnataka 570001, India

reviews.reviewText: The Mysore Palace is a true architectural wonder. The intricate carvings, beautiful domes, and royal interiors are a feast for the eyes. I was amazed by how grand and majestic the entire place felt. The evening light show made it even more magical. It's a must-visit place if you're in Karnataka. Highly recommended for history lovers and architecture enthusiasts!

Place is good and Maintained. We went during public holiday so it was so much crowded and we didn't get to see inside of the palace properly. The ticket cost is around 120 Rupees which I didn't think it was worth it as there was no crowd management. But overall good visit and good experience.

Palace is very beautiful ‚ù§Ô∏è

Pros
1. Rich mix of culture and history.
2. Huge campus so it doesn't get crowded.
3. Very well maintained.

Cons
1. Tickets for the Palace is separate from the Light and Sound show.
2. To buy the tickets for the light and aound show you'll have to come outside of the palace again and get in a queue for the tickets.

My visit to Mysore Palace was an incredible experience. This magnificent landmark is a perfect destination for a day trip with family or friends. The palace is absolutely stunning, with a massive structure and intricate architecture that truly make it a highlight of Mysore.
Be prepared for some walking as you explore the beautifully maintained grounds. It's well worth it to take in the details of the palace from every angle. It's also a fantastic place for photography‚Äîthe majestic exteriors and richly decorated interiors provide countless opportunities for amazing photos, whether you're taking portraits or just capturing candid moments.
Within the palace complex, you'll also find a few temples, which add a peaceful and cultural touch to the visit. Overall, it's a memorable place that I highly recommend.

One of the most beautiful palaces in the country that is still being maintained to the best of its heritage, culture, history and the timeless stories that it narrates to all the visitors. Located in the heart of Mysore city, the palace has been holding its charm ever since it was constructed decades ago. Each section of the palace speaks out its legacy of the royal family and their importance in the Mysore dynasty and the Bangalore history. A lot of the palace area is restricted for visitors but the area accessible by the visitors make you drop your jaw while you endure its legacy. It‚Äôs beautiful, architecture is outstanding and the beautifully restored walls. I‚Äôd highly recommend anyone visiting Bangalore of Mysore to visit this place, you‚Äôd not regret your time. The entry ticket is ‚Çπ120 per person and there‚Äôs ample parking space outside. There‚Äôs also toilets after the entry and some food outlets as well. A lot of street vendors outside the palace are selling souvenirs, snacks and everything that you might need for a quick bite.

Only saw it from outside courtyard. Very beautiful from outside, more so in the evening when the entire palace is lit up. Plan to see it from inside next time. Horse cart ride is highly recommended, the long round covers the route around the beautifully lit up palace in the evening covering all 5 palace gates.

Mysore Palace is stunning! The architecture, intricate carvings, and royal interiors are breathtaking. The evening illumination is magical, and the Dussehra celebrations make it even more special. A must-visit to experience the city‚Äôs rich heritage.

Beautiful Palace and with lights on it's even more gorgeous. There are many temples inside and outside all around the palace. The light show happens daily from 7 to 8pm and it is free to enter and see no ticket. You may have to pay for parking though. There are many shops all around to buy eatables and toys and other things like crafts, collectables, etc. It is nice good for taking a walk near a scenic and beautiful place.

reviews.reviewText:
Jagmohan Palace is a true gem of Mysore! The architecture is stunning, showcasing intricate designs and a glimpse of royal heritage. The art gallery inside is a treasure trove for history and art enthusiasts, with an impressive collection of paintings, artifacts, and cultural exhibits. The maintenance of the palace is commendable, and the serene ambiance adds to the experience.

A must-visit for anyone exploring Mysore, whether you're into art, history, or simply admire beautiful architecture. Parking is convenient, and the staff is friendly and helpful. Highly recommended for tourists and locals alike!
Hidden gem of mysore, not a popular place visited by tourist. But must visit if you are art enthusiast. You can see Ravi varma originals here. üòç

If you are an art enthusiast, have 1-2 hours to peacefully stand and stare at the art pieces wondering at their beauty and reading about them, then this definitely is a perfect place for you. Kids might not find it very interesting as it is a collection of paintings and other art collections.
Needs a little more maintenance because the floors are squeaky and rooms are dusty. Some of the paintings are getting ruined and it's very disheartening.

Otherwise it's a very beautiful place !

Visiting the Jaganmohan Palace in Mysuru offers a captivating blend of royal heritage and artistic brilliance. Originally constructed in 1861 by Maharaja Krishnaraja Wodeyar III, this palace served as the royal residence during the reconstruction of the Mysore Palace after a fire. Today, it houses the Sri Jayachamarajendra Art Gallery, showcasing an extensive collection of over 2,000 artworks.

private palace of mysuru dynasty..now converted to art gallery ...it's all about private collection of the kings ..the top floor showcases the love of mummadi krishnaraja wadiyar for dice games with whole room walls filled with various dice games paintings

Shri Jayachamarajendra Art Gallery, housed in the magnificent Jaganmohan Palace, is a must-visit for art and history lovers in Mysore. The gallery features a rich collection of paintings, artifacts, and royal memorabilia, including works by Raja Ravi Varma and other renowned artists. The blend of traditional and modern art gives visitors a deep appreciation for India's artistic heritage.

A must visit art gallery in the close vicinity of mysore palace and stored many historical artefacts original and replicated paintings awesome photographs etc. the main old building area is well curated and display is excellent. But the new attached portion is little ill maintained. You can visit this place just to see the one magical painting the lady with the lamp. Ticket price will be worth by that one painting itself.

A hidden gem for art and history lovers! The palace houses an incredible collection of paintings, including works by Raja Ravi Varma. Peaceful, well-maintained, and full of cultural charm. Perfect for a quiet, enriching visit.

placeMetadata.name: Melody World Wax Museum

sources.snippet: At a distance of around 3 km from Mysore Palace, on the Vihara Marg, Kurubara Halli, this is another popular and unique museum of Mysore city. Housed inside a heritage building, this museum has the largest collection of musical instruments in Karnataka. Apart from varied traditional and ancient musical instruments, the other major attraction here are the life size wax statues of musicians in traditional attires playing different instruments.

sources.snippet: Unlike typical wax museums,  Melody World Wax Museum is dedicated to music. There are more than 100 wax figures and 300 musical instruments on display in realistic settings. You can see Indian classical concerts and rock bands from around the world, which gives you a global view of music traditions.

Great fun and informative place, definitely a visit will reward your time!

The whole concept of this is worth appreciating. The idea of wax statues to hold the real traditional musical instruments is just awesome. The maintenance is not that great. They could have arranged decent rooms. Also the add-ons are good. Worth place to visit once

Good collections of antique instruments, devices, utensils, cultural artifacts, etc.
The mirror maze was excellent.
The Horror house was average, not scary at all.
The place needs maintenance though.

Was amazed by the amount of musical instruments collected by them. For them to run this privately without any outside funds and collect so many instruments speaks a lot about their Passion towards collecting the music instruments.

I recently visited the **Melody World Wax Museum** in Mysuru, and it was a wonderful experience. reviews.reviewText:
A Hidden Gem of Mysore
The Regional Museum of Natural History
Nestled in the heart of Mysore, the Regional Museum of Natural History is a treasure trove of knowledge waiting to be discovered. This often-overlooked gem offers a captivating journey through the wonders of the natural world, and it's completely free to explore!
The museum is divided into three distinct sections: the Temporary Exhibition, the Biological Diversity Center, and the Discovery Center. Each section offers a unique perspective on the natural world, from the intricate details of local flora and fauna to the fascinating story of evolution.
One of the highlights is the impressive collection of taxidermied specimens.  Leopards, cheetahs, tigers, wild bears, turtles, snakes, and a diverse array of birds are showcased, offering a glimpse into the incredible diversity of wildlife found in India.  The preserved skeleton of a Bryde's Whale is a truly remarkable sight, a testament to the museum's commitment to showcasing the majesty of the natural world.
The museum is meticulously maintained and organized, making it an engaging experience for visitors of all ages.  With free entry and ample parking, it's a truly accessible and enjoyable destination.  Whether you're a wildlife enthusiast, a student, or simply curious about the world around you, the Regional Museum of Natural History in Mysore is a must-visit destination. It's a hidden gem that deserves to be celebrated and supported.

Highly Recommended!

It's a free entry place the place is so so spacious, amidst of greenery fresh air and nature.  It's a wonderful initiative from govt. The place is yet to be developed. But has wide variety of specimen collection. It's so knowledgeable to school and college children. It's so educational. U can visit this place.

I made it a point to drop by here just to have a look at the museum for Elementary Schools. In fact, I personally feel that the young and old can benefit in achieving a better understanding of India‚Äôs efforts in preservation of its own waters/soils.

Simplicity is the key to telling and advocating its objectives. Crafts were done neatly and I liked their creativity. Nothing too fancy but just basic.

I didn‚Äôt realise that there are still many tribal members in India, let alone the different types of spoken languages.

There were a few different  halls, each exhibiting different topics.

I liked their creativity as well as the information shared. The caretakers were friendly, they encouraged me to touch & feel the artefacts in the hall where the skulls of elephant / giraffe / dolphin were displayed.

Definitely pleased to have visited this down-to-earth museum. It does take quite an effort to maintain it and thank you for that. Great job!

Entry is FOC.

It was a decent museum. For a museum that suprisingly had no entry fees, I would say it was worth it. Could be far better for a government maintained museum. It's a decent spot to take kids for an educational short tour. The discovery section was my favourite where they had collections of skeletons of various animals. The different exhibits of various biomes were really nice to see.

Its a dedicated museum of natural history as name suggests. It's in a calm green location. Place itself is wonderful. It has information on evolution, tribes, life and current challenges for us to survive.

One of the hidden gems and underutilised museums in Mysore.

Kukkarahalli Lake in Mysuru is a serene and scenic destination, perfect for nature lovers, joggers, and birdwatchers alike. Nestled within the heart of the city, the lake offers a peaceful 4.5 km walking trail surrounded by lush greenery, making it an ideal spot for early morning walks or relaxing evening strolls. Visitors often praise the area for its cleanliness, cool shade from trees, and abundance of birds‚Äîespecially during migratory seasons. The lake is home to species like pelicans, storks, and kingfishers, attracting photographers and wildlife enthusiasts. Though boating has been discontinued, the charm of the lake remains intact, with quiet corners to sit, reflect, or write. Some minor concerns include occasional water quality issues and a lack of public restrooms. Despite this, Kukkarahalli Lake continues to be a beloved urban escape, celebrated not only for its ecological beauty but also its cultural heritage, having inspired many local writers and poets. Entry is free, and the lake is easily accessible from key areas of Mysore.

My visit to Lokaranjan Aqua World Underwater Zoo was a delightful and educational experience. The aquarium is home to a wide variety of fascinating marine life, with beautifully designed tanks that offer clear views of colorful fish, graceful rays, and majestic turtles. The thematic layout and creative displays make the journey enjoyable for both kids and adults, sparking curiosity about aquatic ecosystems and species.

One of the highlights was the underwater tunnel, which lets you feel surrounded by aquatic creatures swimming overhead‚Äîa truly immersive experience. The zoo also offers informative boards and interactive sessions that helped deepen our understanding of marine conservation. The friendly staff were always ready to answer questions and guide visitors, adding warmth to the visit.

The only reason I‚Äôm giving 4 stars instead of 5 is that a few sections felt a bit crowded, and there could be more seating areas to relax between exhibits. However, overall, Lokaranjan Aqua World is a fantastic place for a family outing, school trip, or a casual exploration. I left with a smile and would certainly recommend it to anyone looking for a fun and educational stop in the city!

Mysuru has so many wonderful attractions, but sadly, Lokaranjan Aqua World does not live up to expectations. placeMetadata.name: Sri Chamarajendra Zoological Gardens (Mysuru Zoo)

sources.snippet: Commonly referred as Mysore Zoo, Shri Chamarajendra Zoological Gardens is placed adjacent to Karanji lake. One of the oldest zoos in the country, it was established in 1892 by the Kings of Mysore as part of the summer palace of Maharaja Sri Chamaraja Wodeyar. It features as one of the most popular tourist places in Mysore.

Visited the Mysore Zoo and had a great experience!!! The zoo is very well maintained, clean, and has a wide variety of animals, birds, and reptiles.

There's a clear walking path, drinking water, rest rooms, souvenir shop and shaded rest spots.

It‚Äôs a peaceful place to enjoy nature and wildlife. It took about 2‚Äì4 hours to cover fully depending on how you want to cover.

Highly recommended for families, kids, and nature lovers. It felt good to see such a well organized zoo with a variety of species.

I recently visited Mysore Zoo and had a wonderful experience. The place is very well maintained with clean and green surroundings, which makes walking around really pleasant. The animal enclosures are neat and tidy, and it‚Äôs nice to see that the animals are kept in good care. It‚Äôs also a lovely spot for kids ‚Äì they really enjoy seeing such a wide variety of animals up close. The only thing that could be improved is the canteen, which was a bit disappointing compared to the overall standard of the zoo. Otherwise, it‚Äôs definitely a place worth visiting when in Mysore.

Clean, green and really well run‚ÄîMysore Zoo is a pleasure to walk. Enclosures feel spacious, the collection is superb (great apes, big cats, giraffes), and the paths are shaded with plenty of drinking-water points. Staff are efficient, battery buggies/wheelchairs help elders, and the plastic-free policy is a big plus. It gets crowded on weekends and the loop is long, so wear comfy shoes. Overall: a fantastic family outing and wildlife lover‚Äôs stop.

Pro tip: Go early for active animals, then wind down at nearby Karanji Lake.

Wild Wonders Await! ü¶Åüêòü¶ì

Spent a full day at this zoo and it was totally worth it! You can see all kinds of animals here‚Äîfrom big cats and elephants to birds and reptiles. Every creature looked healthy and well taken care of, which made the visit even more enjoyable.

üö∂‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Size & Time: The zoo is huge. Be ready for a lot of walking‚Äîit takes time to cover everything, so go with full energy and comfy shoes.

üöó Transport Option: They do offer internal transport, but the wait was too long, so we skipped it. Might be useful if you‚Äôre visiting with elders or small kids, but plan accordingly.

üéâ For Kids: It‚Äôs a paradise! Kids will absolutely love seeing the animals up close and the wide open spaces to explore.

üíö Reminder: Please be kind to the animals. Don‚Äôt tap on enclosures or try to feed them‚Äîjust enjoy observing!

üì∑ Bonus Tip: Great spots for family photos along the way!

The zoo offered a wonderful experience for everyone. The animals were well-cared for and the habitats were thoughtfully designed. It was clear that the staff was dedicated to the animals' well-being. I appreciate the effort put into making this zoo a great place to visit. Overall, it was an amazing and excellent experience.

A Fun Day Out, but Pack Your Patience (and Snacks!)
The zoo is a great destination for a family day, especially if you have children. It's an excellent opportunity to see a wide variety of animals.
We considered the battery car, but I'm glad we decided against it. As some have mentioned, it's not the best way to experience the zoo. You'll miss most of the details and close-up views of the animals, which is the main reason to go. Walking around is definitely the way to go, even with kids.
A definite highlight was the Karanji Lake. The boating experience was a fantastic memory and a welcome break from walking. It's a must-do for anyone visiting.
The one major drawback, however, is the food situation. Food is not allowed inside, which is understandable, but the on-site restaurant is quite disappointing. The quality and variety were poor, making it difficult to refuel after a long walk. It would be a huge improvement if they had a food court with multiple vendors offering a better selection of refreshing drinks and meals.
Overall, it's a great place for a family outing, but be prepared for the food court frustration. Plan your visit accordingly, perhaps by eating a large meal before or after you go.

I recently visited the Mysore Zoo and had an absolutely amazing experience. This place is truly a gem for anyone who loves nature, wildlife, or just wants to spend a peaceful and entertaining day outdoors. The zoo is very big and extremely well-maintained, making it one of the best zoos I‚Äôve visited in India.

The variety of animals here is genuinely impressive. From elephants, giraffes, and rhinos to big cats like cheetahs, leopards, and even a majestic black panther ‚Äî the zoo is home to a wide range of species. What stood out the most was how close you can get to these animals (safely, of course). Seeing these creatures up close was a very unique and unforgettable experience.

The zoo also has a large section dedicated to reptiles and birds. Although there was a bit of crowding near the reptile section, it was still manageable and didn't take away from the experience. You‚Äôll find crocodiles, snakes, and many fascinating species that are not commonly seen elsewhere.

One of the most entertaining parts of the visit was watching the monkeys play. They swing around on ropes and entertain visitors with their antics ‚Äî fun for both kids and adults alike. We were also thrilled to see a gorilla, which is quite rare in Indian zoos.

The environment inside the zoo is clean, green, and well-organized. Safety measures are in place throughout the zoo, and the staff seem to be doing a good job managing both animals and visitors. There are plenty of signboards, shaded walking paths, and resting spots to make your visit comfortable.

As for the ticket prices, they are quite reasonable. It‚Äôs ‚Çπ120 per person if you choose to walk, and ‚Çπ240 per person if you take the battery-operated vehicle. The battery vehicle is a good option if you're visiting with elderly people or young children, and it accommodates about 8 people at a time.

Overall, the Mysore Zoo offers a perfect blend of education, entertainment, and relaxation. Whether you're a tourist or a local resident, this place should definitely be on your list. Highly recommended for a fun-filled day with family or friends!

placeMetadata.name: Folklore Museum

sources.snippet: Another interesting museum to visit in Mysore is the Folklore Museum. Established in 1968, this museum, as the name suggests, focusses on the varied folk arts and crafts of Karnataka. It has a rich collection of more than 6500 archives about dance, literature, music and various other arts forms from all over the state.

The Mysuru Rail Museum is a captivating destination for train enthusiasts and history buffs alike. Located in Mysuru, Karnataka, this museum offers a fascinating journey through the evolution of Indian railways.

Opened in 1979, the museum is housed in the historic Mysuru Railway Station building, which itself is an architectural marvel dating back to the British colonial era. The museum's collection includes vintage locomotives, coaches, and artifacts that showcase the technological advancements and cultural significance of railways in India.

One of the highlights of the Mysuru Rail Museum is its impressive display of locomotives from different eras, including steam, diesel, and electric engines. Visitors can marvel at the intricate craftsmanship and engineering marvels that powered India's railway system through the decades.

In addition to locomotives, the museum also features a variety of railway memorabilia, including antique signaling equipment, ticketing machines, and historical photographs documenting the evolution of Indian Railways.

A visit to the Mysuru Rail Museum offers not only a glimpse into the past but also an opportunity to learn about the role of railways in shaping the socio-economic landscape of India. The museum's interactive exhibits and informative displays provide visitors with a deeper understanding of the history, technology, and cultural significance of Indian railways.

Whether you're a railway enthusiast, a history buff, or simply curious about India's rich heritage, the Mysuru Rail Museum promises an engaging and educational experience for visitors of all ages. It's a journey through time that celebrates the legacy of one of the country's most iconic modes of transportation.

captures the essence of Mysore's local culture. It's a bustling marketplace filled with fresh fruits, vegetables, flowers, spices, and traditional items. The fragrance of jasmine and incense sticks, combined with the vivid colors of fruits and flowers, creates an unforgettable sensory experience.

stepping into Devaraja Market in Mysore is like entering a completely different world ‚Äì a vibrant, sensory overload in the best possible way! It's not your typical sterile shopping experience; it's raw, it's bustling, and it's full of life.
The first thing that hits you is the explosion of colors and smells. Piles upon piles of bright fruits and vegetables are everywhere ‚Äì the deep red of tomatoes, the vibrant yellow of bananas, the lush green of leafy vegetables. And the fragrance? A mix of sweet flowers, earthy spices, and fresh produce all mingling together. It‚Äôs quite intoxicating!
What I loved is how authentic it feels. You see local vendors, many of whom have been there for generations, passionately selling their goods. There's a real buzz of interaction between them and the customers, a friendly banter that you don't often find in modern supermarkets.
You can find pretty much anything here, from fresh produce and flowers (oh, the marigolds and jasmine are just gorgeous!) to spices, incense, and even some household items. It‚Äôs a feast for the senses at every turn.
Navigating through the narrow pathways can be a bit chaotic, with people and handcarts moving around, but that's part of its charm. It feels like you're right in the heart of the city's everyday life.
I spent a good amount of time just wandering around, taking it all in. I bought some fragrant spices and a few local fruits that I hadn't tried before. It felt good to support the local economy directly.
It's not a fancy, air-conditioned mall; it's a traditional market, and it has all the character that comes with that. If you want to experience the real pulse of Mysore and soak in the local culture, Devaraja Market is a must-visit. Just be prepared for the crowds and the sensory overload ‚Äì embrace it, and you'll have a fantastic time!

Mysore Market, also known as Devaraja Market, is one of the oldest and most iconic marketplaces in Karnataka. Located in the center of Mysore city, it‚Äôs not just a shopping destination‚Äîit‚Äôs a cultural experience in itself. Walking through the market feels like stepping into a different world, where tradition and daily life blend seamlessly.

The first thing you‚Äôll notice is the explosion of colors‚Äîbright orange marigolds, red chilies, green herbs, and vibrant pigments used for religious and decorative purposes. The air is filled with the scent of fresh flowers, spices, and incense, creating a sensory experience that‚Äôs truly unforgettable. Stalls are lined with fresh produce, aromatic oils, sandalwood products, and handmade items that reflect the craftsmanship of local artisans.

The market is well-organized, with separate sections for fruits and vegetables, flowers, puja items, and household goods. It‚Äôs a great place to interact with locals, many of whom are eager to share stories or explain the use of their products. The vendors are generally friendly and open to bargaining, making it a fun place to shop.

What sets Mysore Market apart is its authenticity. Unlike commercial malls, it offers a raw and genuine glimpse into the daily life of Mysore‚Äôs residents. It‚Äôs also a photographer‚Äôs dream, filled with colorful scenes and lively characters.

Whether you're a traveler, a photographer, a foodie, or just curious, Mysore Market is a must-visit. It‚Äôs more than a place to shop‚Äîit's a place to connect with Mysore‚Äôs soul.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Mysuru, often referred to as the City of Palaces, is a treasure trove of stunning architecture and vibrant culture, making it a photographer's dream. From the majestic Mysore Palace, with its intricate designs and colorful interiors, to the serene beauty of the Kishkindha Moolika Bonsai Garden, this city offers countless opportunities to capture breathtaking moments. Whether you're wandering through the lush landscapes of the Sri Chamarajendra Zoological Gardens or marveling at the intricate sand sculptures at the Sand Museum, each corner of Mysuru tells a unique story waiting to be framed.

As you explore this enchanting city, you'll discover a delightful mix of historical landmarks and hidden gems that provide the perfect backdrop for your travel memories. The Wanderlog team is passionate about uncovering the best spots to snap that perfect picture, from the ornate details of St. Philomena's Cathedral to the whimsical displays at the Melody World Wax Museum. So grab your camera and get ready to explore the picturesque streets and stunning sights of Mysuru, where every click can capture a piece of its rich heritage and charm.

placeMetadata.name: Jaganmohana Palace (Sri Jayachamarajendra Art Gallery) And Auditorium

sources.snippet: Jaganmohan Palace, situated in the heart of Mysuru, was constructed in 1869 by Maharaja Krishnaraja Wodeyar III. Initially used as a residence for the royal family during the reconstruction of Amba Vilas Palace, it now houses the Jayachamarajendra Art Gallery, renowned as one of South India's premier art galleries. The palace is notable for its grand wooden doors, adorned with carvings of the Dashavatara (the ten incarnations of Vishnu), and murals depicting the Mysore Dasara and the Wadiyar lineage. Open daily from 8 AM to 5:30 PM, it is located 2 km from both Mysore Railway Station and the KSRTC Bus Station.
sources.shortName: Seven Palaces In Mysore That Make It The ‚ÄúCity Of Palaces‚Äù | News

sources.snippet: Situated in the majestic city of Mysore, the Jaganmohan Palace is a spectacular edifice that has an illustrious history attached to its name. Built in the year 1869, it was used by the Wodeyars of Mysore when their main residence Amba Vilas Palace was under renovations post a fire accident. Timings: 8 AM - 5:30 PM Entry Fee: INR 25 per adults; INR 10 per children (5-10 years old)Location: Jagan Mohan Palace Road, Subbarayanakere, Chamrajpura, Mysuru
sources.shortName: 7 Palaces in Mysore For A Historic and Regal Experience (2024)

sources.snippet: Once famous as a home to the kings of Mysore, Jaganmohan Palace Art Gallery and Auditorium is housed within the Jaganmohan Palace which was established in 1861. It is one of the seven palaces in the city. Regarded as one of the most impeccable contributions of Wodeyar Kings, the palace, one of the most important Mysore tourist places, is now an art gallery as well as a function hall.
sources.shortName: 35 Places to Visit in Mysore, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: The three-storeyed structure of Jaganmohan Palace was the residing place of the Wodeyars, the Kings of Mysore, while the Mysore palace was being rebuilt after it was burnt down in 1897. The structure is built using traditional Hindu style of architecture. The walls inside the palace have beautiful painted murals that catch the eyes of tourists.
sources.shortName: Best 3 Palaces in Mysore

sources.snippet: The Jaganmohan Palace, built in 1861, served as the royal residence until the current Mysore Palace was constructed. Today, it functions as an art gallery with a vast collection of paintings, including masterpieces by Raja Ravi Varma, that showcase Indian art and heritage. A view of the Jaganmohan Palace, Mysore | Shutterstock
sources.shortName: Top 10 Palaces To Visit In Mysore

sources.snippet: During these days, the royal family resided in the Jaganmohan Palace. The construction of the new Mysore Palace was commissioned during the year 1897 and it was completed in the year 1912. The palace was expanded by the Maharaja Sri Jayachamarajendra Wadiyar during the year 1940.
sources.shortName: Palaces in Mysore, Historical Palaces in Mysore, Mahal in Mysore

sources.snippet: Located in the heart of Mysore city, the Jaganmohan Palace was built in 1869 by Maharaja Krishnaraja Wodeyar 3. The family moved here when the Mysore Palace was being reconstructed after an accident. The Jaganmohan palace has now been converted into an art gallery.
sources.shortName: 6 Most famous Palaces in Mysore | Palaces to Visit in Mysore

sources.snippet: The beautiful Jaganmohan Palace is located in the centre of Mysuru city. Maharaja Krishnaraja Wodeyar III had it built in 1869. The royal family moved in and lived here when the main palace, Amba Vilas, was under construction after it burnt down in an accident.

placeMetadata.description: Former royal palace built in 1861, now a gallery displaying paintings, carvings & other artifacts.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Jaganmohan Palace, also known as the Sri Jayachamarajendra Art Gallery, is a historic site located near Mysore City Bus Stand. Originally built in 1861 as a royal retreat, it now houses an impressive art gallery featuring paintings, carvings, and other artifacts. The palace showcases a diverse collection of artworks including paintings by renowned artists like Raja Ravi Varma and Col. Scot, depicting scenes from Hindu epics and historical conflicts.
placeMetadata.address: 8J4X+QW5, Jagan Mohan Palace Road, Subbarayanakere, Chamrajpura, Mysuru, Karnataka 570004, India

reviews.reviewText:
Jagmohan Palace is a true gem of Mysore! The architecture is stunning, showcasing intricate designs and a glimpse of royal heritage. The art gallery inside is a treasure trove for history and art enthusiasts, with an impressive collection of paintings, artifacts, and cultural exhibits. The maintenance of the palace is commendable, and the serene ambiance adds to the experience.

A must-visit for anyone exploring Mysore, whether you're into art, history, or simply admire beautiful architecture. Parking is convenient, and the staff is friendly and helpful. Highly recommended for tourists and locals alike!
Hidden gem of mysore, not a popular place visited by tourist. But must visit if you are art enthusiast. You can see Ravi varma originals here. üòç

If you are an art enthusiast, have 1-2 hours to peacefully stand and stare at the art pieces wondering at their beauty and reading about them, then this definitely is a perfect place for you. Kids might not find it very interesting as it is a collection of paintings and other art collections.
Needs a little more maintenance because the floors are squeaky and rooms are dusty. Some of the paintings are getting ruined and it's very disheartening.

Otherwise it's a very beautiful place !

Visiting the Jaganmohan Palace in Mysuru offers a captivating blend of royal heritage and artistic brilliance. Originally constructed in 1861 by Maharaja Krishnaraja Wodeyar III, this palace served as the royal residence during the reconstruction of the Mysore Palace after a fire. Today, it houses the Sri Jayachamarajendra Art Gallery, showcasing an extensive collection of over 2,000 artworks.

private palace of mysuru dynasty..now converted to art gallery ...it's all about private collection of the kings ..the top floor showcases the love of mummadi krishnaraja wadiyar for dice games with whole room walls filled with various dice games paintings

Shri Jayachamarajendra Art Gallery, housed in the magnificent Jaganmohan Palace, is a must-visit for art and history lovers in Mysore. The gallery features a rich collection of paintings, artifacts, and royal memorabilia, including works by Raja Ravi Varma and other renowned artists. The blend of traditional and modern art gives visitors a deep appreciation for India's artistic heritage.

A must visit art gallery in the close vicinity of mysore palace and stored many historical artefacts original and replicated paintings awesome photographs etc. the main old building area is well curated and display is excellent. But the new attached portion is little ill maintained. You can visit this place just to see the one magical painting the lady with the lamp. Ticket price will be worth by that one painting itself.

A hidden gem for art and history lovers! The palace houses an incredible collection of paintings, including works by Raja Ravi Varma. Peaceful, well-maintained, and full of cultural charm. Perfect for a quiet, enriching visit.

placeMetadata.name: Mysuru Palace

sources.snippet: An incredibly breathtaking example of Indo - Saracenic style of architecture, the Mysore Palace is a magnificent edifice located in Mysore in the state of Karnataka. Also known as the Amba Vilas Palace, it is the former palace of the royal family of Mysore and is still their official residence.Timings: 10 AM - 5:30 PM Entry Fee: INR 50 per adults (and foreign tourists); INR 30 per children (10- 18 years old)Location: Sayyaji Rao Rd, Agrahara, Chamrajpura, Mysuru
sources.shortName: 7 Palaces in Mysore For A Historic and Regal Experience (2024)

sources.snippet: Mysore Palace, also known as Amba Vilas Palace, is the pride of Mysore and one of India's most famous tourist attractions, drawing over 6 million visitors annually. Built in 1912 in the Indo-Saracenic style, it blends Hindu, Mughal, Rajput, and Gothic architectural elements. The palace features grey granite walls, pink marble domes, expansive arches, and a 145-foot tower with a gold-plated dome.
sources.shortName: Seven Palaces In Mysore That Make It The ‚ÄúCity Of Palaces‚Äù | News

sources.snippet: Mysore Palace, otherwise called Amba Vilas Palace, situated at the core of Mysore city is the most unmistakable vacationer goal of Mysore and pulls in a huge number of guests through the year. This recorded castle housed inside the Old Fort fronting the Chamunda Hills remains as the official living arrangement of the Wadiyar administration, who governed the Kingdom of Mysore from 1399 to 1950.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Things To Do In Mysuru (Mysore), India

sources.snippet: The Mysore Palace is also called as the Amba Vilas PAlace is located in the Mysore City in the state of Karnataka. This palace has been constructed in the past centuries and it holds a big history behind the origination of such a great palace in Mysore. The Mysore Palace was once the official residence of the famous Wodeyars, who were known as the most royal family in the city of Mysore.
sources.shortName: Palaces in Mysore, Historical Palaces in Mysore, Mahal in Mysore

sources.snippet: One of India's most important tourist destinations, the  Mysore palace visit is a must on your visit to the city. This iconic landmark attracts millions of tourists from all across the world every year. The Indo-Saracenic style of architecture is a beautiful blend of various architecture styles adopted from Hindu, Buddhist, Gothic, Mughal, and Rajput cultures.
sources.shortName: 6 Most famous Palaces in Mysore | Palaces to Visit in Mysore

sources.snippet: The city‚Äôs proudest possession and most iconic landmark is the magnificent Mysore Palace. Home of the erstwhile rulers of Mysore, it is now among the famous tourist attractions in India that attracts over 6 million tourists every year. Originally built in the fifth century, this palace has since been demolished and reconstructed and renovated several times.
sources.shortName: 7 Palaces In Mysore You Must Visit

sources.snippet: The Mysore Palace, completed in 1912, is a stunning example of Indo-Saracenic architecture. It serves as the official residence of the Wodeyar dynasty and features a grand durbar hall, intricate interiors, and an annual illumination during the Dasara festival. A view of the Mysore Palace | Shutterstock
sources.shortName: Top 10 Palaces To Visit In Mysore

sources.snippet: The shimmering structure can't be forgotten if you have visited it once. Located at the heart of the city, the palace is a national treasure and pride of Mysore city. The original structure was built in wood and was burnt down in 1897 and rebuilt in 1912.
sources.shortName: Best 3 Palaces in Mysore

placeMetadata.description: Indo-Saracenic palace, completed in 1912, with a grand durbar hall and weekly illuminations.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Mysore Palace, a stunning Indo-Saracenic architectural marvel completed in 1912, boasts a grand durbar hall and hosts weekly illuminations. The palace is famous for the traditional Dasara procession, Jamboo Savari, featuring a decorated elephant carrying the idol of Goddess Chamundeshwari during Vijaya Dashami. This centuries-old celebration was initiated by Raja Wodeyar in 1610 and has continued uninterrupted.
placeMetadata.address: Agrahara, Chamrajpura, Mysuru, Karnataka 570001, India

reviews.reviewText: The Mysore Palace is a true architectural wonder. The intricate carvings, beautiful domes, and royal interiors are a feast for the eyes. I was amazed by how grand and majestic the entire place felt. The evening light show made it even more magical. It's a must-visit place if you're in Karnataka. Highly recommended for history lovers and architecture enthusiasts!

Place is good and Maintained. We went during public holiday so it was so much crowded and we didn't get to see inside of the palace properly. The ticket cost is around 120 Rupees which I didn't think it was worth it as there was no crowd management. But overall good visit and good experience.

Palace is very beautiful ‚ù§Ô∏è

Pros
1. Rich mix of culture and history.
2. Huge campus so it doesn't get crowded.
3. Very well maintained.

Cons
1. Tickets for the Palace is separate from the Light and Sound show.
2. To buy the tickets for the light and aound show you'll have to come outside of the palace again and get in a queue for the tickets.

My visit to Mysore Palace was an incredible experience. This magnificent landmark is a perfect destination for a day trip with family or friends. The palace is absolutely stunning, with a massive structure and intricate architecture that truly make it a highlight of Mysore.
Be prepared for some walking as you explore the beautifully maintained grounds. It's well worth it to take in the details of the palace from every angle. It's also a fantastic place for photography‚Äîthe majestic exteriors and richly decorated interiors provide countless opportunities for amazing photos, whether you're taking portraits or just capturing candid moments.
Within the palace complex, you'll also find a few temples, which add a peaceful and cultural touch to the visit. Overall, it's a memorable place that I highly recommend.

One of the most beautiful palaces in the country that is still being maintained to the best of its heritage, culture, history and the timeless stories that it narrates to all the visitors. Located in the heart of Mysore city, the palace has been holding its charm ever since it was constructed decades ago. Each section of the palace speaks out its legacy of the royal family and their importance in the Mysore dynasty and the Bangalore history. A lot of the palace area is restricted for visitors but the area accessible by the visitors make you drop your jaw while you endure its legacy. It‚Äôs beautiful, architecture is outstanding and the beautifully restored walls. I‚Äôd highly recommend anyone visiting Bangalore of Mysore to visit this place, you‚Äôd not regret your time. The entry ticket is ‚Çπ120 per person and there‚Äôs ample parking space outside. There‚Äôs also toilets after the entry and some food outlets as well. A lot of street vendors outside the palace are selling souvenirs, snacks and everything that you might need for a quick bite.

Only saw it from outside courtyard. Very beautiful from outside, more so in the evening when the entire palace is lit up. Plan to see it from inside next time. Horse cart ride is highly recommended, the long round covers the route around the beautifully lit up palace in the evening covering all 5 palace gates.

Mysore Palace is stunning! The architecture, intricate carvings, and royal interiors are breathtaking. The evening illumination is magical, and the Dussehra celebrations make it even more special. A must-visit to experience the city‚Äôs rich heritage.

Beautiful Palace and with lights on it's even more gorgeous. There are many temples inside and outside all around the palace. The light show happens daily from 7 to 8pm and it is free to enter and see no ticket. You may have to pay for parking though. There are many shops all around to buy eatables and toys and other things like crafts, collectables, etc. It is nice good for taking a walk near a scenic and beautiful place.

placeMetadata.name: Jayalakshmi Vilas Mansion

sources.snippet: Jayalakshmi Vilas, constructed in 1905 by Maharaja Chamaraja Wodeyar for his eldest daughter, Princess Jayalakshmi Ammani, was originally known as the First Rajkumari Mansion. Situated on a hillock west of Kukkarahalli Lake, the palace is now part of the University of Mysore and houses the Manasagangotri postgraduate center. After years of neglect, it was renovated from 2002 to 2006 with a donation from the Infosys Foundation.
sources.shortName: Seven Palaces In Mysore That Make It The ‚ÄúCity Of Palaces‚Äù | News

sources.snippet: Maharaja Chamaraja Wodeyar built this mansion for his daughter, Princess Jayalakshmi Ammani. It is located on a hillock next to a scenic lake and is now a part of the University of Mysore. The University of Mysore acquired the palace to establish the postgraduate centre.

Lokaranjan Mahal Palace.

This palace is located in a brickyard in Mysore. Built in 1842, this palace is also known as the summer palace of the Maharaja of Mysore. Earlier it was also the residence of the royal family. In later days, it is said that it was the school of Tenth Chamaraja Wodeyar and Nalwadi Krishnaraja Wodeyar. Moreover, the Vishwa Hindu Mahaparishad Grand Conference was also held in Lokaranjan Palace under the chairmanship of Sriman Maharaja Jayachamarajendra Wodeyar. The palace is located near the Chamarajendra Zoo in Mysore and is currently the residence of the dignitaries.

placeMetadata.description: Mysore (or Mysuru), a city in India's southwestern Karnataka state, was the capital of the Kingdom of Mysore from 1399 to 1947. In its center is opulent Mysore Palace, seat of the former ruling Wodeyar dynasty. The palace blends Hindu, Islamic, Gothic and Rajput styles. Mysore is also home to the centuries-old Devaraja Market, filled with spices, silk and sandalwood.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Mysuru, a city in the southwestern Karnataka state of India, served as the capital of the Kingdom of Mysore for nearly 550 years. The opulent Mysore Palace, a blend of Hindu, Islamic, Gothic and Rajput styles, stands at its center and was once home to the ruling Wodeyar dynasty. This city is also known for its centuries-old Devaraja Market offering an array of spices, silk and sandalwood.

Krishkindha Moolika Bonsai Garden in Mysore offers a truly unique experience, different from the usual botanical gardens. It‚Äôs a beautifully maintained garden featuring an impressive collection of bonsai plants, each carefully shaped and nurtured with dedication.

The peaceful atmosphere, combined with the artistic display of miniature trees, makes it a calming and inspiring place to visit. It‚Äôs clear that a lot of effort and love has gone into curating this space.

You will find trees planted in 1942 !

There is hundred rupees charge to visit this garden which also includes visit to the museum. The museum is nice and holds the biggest Bhagwat Geeta book which is recorded in Guinness Book of World record as the biggest book.

This hidden gem is perfect for nature lovers, photographers, and those looking to spend quiet, meaningful time surrounded by greenery. Highly recommended for anyone visiting Mysore‚Äîdon‚Äôt miss it!

Bonsai Garden is renowned for its exquisite collection of miniature trees, One of the more unique attractions of the Royal Mysore, the Bonsai Garden of Mysore is home to over a 100 different varieties of Bonsai trees spread across this vast estate.
The garden now hosts 450 miniature tree across an area of 4 acres, filled with these quirky dwarf trees. The beauty of the garden is accentuated by the stream that flows within, as well as the placement of Buddha statues and monkey statues around the area, representative of the zen culture from where the art of Bonsai was evolved.

Excellently maintained bonsai park with lots and lots of trees. The adjoining museum is very big and has four floors . Declared as a heritage building by the Karnataka Government, Jayalakshmi Vilas Palace is one of the most spectacular palaces of Mysore, the cultural capital of the state. Located in Manasagangothri, Tourists often club both these sightseeing places on a single visit.
Initially called ‚ÄòFirst Rajkumari Mansion‚Äô, Jayalakshmi Vilas Palace was built for princess Jayalakshammanni who was the eldest daughter of Maharaja Chamaraja Wodeyar. The palace has three museums, each presenting a display of rare crafts and arts. Various wings of the palace are connected through arched porticos. The first floor of the palace has Goddess Bhuvaneswari statue placed under a domed cover on its southern side. Towards the northern side, a statue of Goddess Lakshmi has been placed.
Even during that period, the palace had separate drainage system for used water and rainwater, which showcase its architecture fineness. The grand interiors of this palace represent Indian style of d√©cor. One can see exquisite carvings, breathtaking mouldings and arts beautifying the interiors of this palace. The opening timings of the Jayalakshmi Palace are from 10 AM to 1 PM and in evening from 3 PM to 5 PM. Photography is prohibited inside the palace complex.

Mysore Palace is nothing short of a living masterpiece. The moment you step through the grand gates, you‚Äôre transported into the royal world of the Wadiyar dynasty. The architecture is absolutely stunning ‚Äì a perfect blend of Hindu, Mughal, Rajput, and Gothic styles that will leave you speechless.

Inside, every hall is more magnificent than the last, with stained glass ceilings, intricately carved doors, and royal artifacts that tell the story of Mysore‚Äôs glorious past. The Kalyana Mantapa (wedding hall) is a true highlight with its colorful peacock-themed ceiling and chandeliers.

But the real magic begins in the evening ‚Äì when the entire palace is illuminated with thousands of lights, it looks like a golden dream come alive! If you get the chance, don‚Äôt miss the light and sound show ‚Äì it beautifully narrates the history of the palace.

Whether you‚Äôre a history lover, architecture enthusiast, or a casual traveler, this place is a must-visit. It‚Äôs clean, well-maintained, and rich in culture.

‚úÖ Stunning interiors
‚úÖ Great for photography
‚úÖ Rich historical experience
‚úÖ Evening lighting is a visual treat

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
One of the best royal palaces in India. A visit you‚Äôll always remember!

Place is good and Maintained. We went during public holiday so it was so much crowded and we didn't get to see inside of the palace properly. The ticket cost is around 120 Rupees which I didn't think it was worth it as there was no crowd management. But overall good visit and good experience.

Palace is very beautiful ‚ù§Ô∏è

My visit to Mysore Palace was an incredible experience. This magnificent landmark is a perfect destination for a day trip with family or friends. The palace is absolutely stunning, with a massive structure and intricate architecture that truly make it a highlight of Mysore.
Be prepared for some walking as you explore the beautifully maintained grounds. It's well worth it to take in the details of the palace from every angle. It's also a fantastic place for photography‚Äîthe majestic exteriors and richly decorated interiors provide countless opportunities for amazing photos, whether you're taking portraits or just capturing candid moments.
Within the palace complex, you'll also find a few temples, which add a peaceful and cultural touch to the visit. Overall, it's a memorable place that I highly recommend.

Pros
1. Rich mix of culture and history.
2. Huge campus so it doesn't get crowded.
3. Very well maintained.

Cons
1. Tickets for the Palace is separate from the Light and Sound show.
2. To buy the tickets for the light and aound show you'll have to come outside of the palace again and get in a queue for the tickets.

The Mysore Palace is a true architectural wonder. The intricate carvings, beautiful domes, and royal interiors are a feast for the eyes. I was amazed by how grand and majestic the entire place felt. The evening light show made it even more magical. It's a must-visit place if you're in Karnataka. Highly recommended for history lovers and architecture enthusiasts!

Weekend place we visited with family. Too much crowed in any visit places due to holidays. Inside palace was good but due to crowed we couldn‚Äôt enjoy properly. We need to handle kids very carful. They may miss in crowed . 7pm to 8pm palace lights they will on.
Light show is available on all days but in case rain they don‚Äôt on as it is open place. Clouds with lights of palace was very pleasant. Most of place light shows are at same time so only one we can cover.

Out side place we double decor bus which will take with in city and cover all the major places but one time experience k.bus charge 250/-. Felt expressive. We missed hours ride . Due to cold weather double deck up we seat on open deck it was so cold . Better horse ride we felt. But one time experience must

Mysore Palace is stunning! The architecture, intricate carvings, and royal interiors are breathtaking. The evening illumination is magical, and the Dussehra celebrations make it even more special. A must-visit to experience the city‚Äôs rich heritage.

A must-visit landmark that beautifully blends history, culture, and architectural grandeur. Whether you visit in the morning or evening, the experience is unforgettable.

In the morning, the palace‚Äôs intricate details and royal interiors are best appreciated with fewer crowds. The natural light highlights its stunning design and craftsmanship.

By evening, the palace transforms into a glowing spectacle when illuminated‚Äîtruly magical and perfect for photography. The ambiance becomes even more enchanting with the lights and the peaceful surroundings.

Highly recommended for anyone visiting Mysore‚Äîdon‚Äôt miss the light show if you're around in the evening

placeMetadata.name: LALITHA Mahal

sources.snippet: The Lalitha Mahal Palace was built in 1921 for the Viceroy of India. St. Paul's Cathedral in London inspired this elegant white structure. It has been transformed into a luxury hotel featuring opulent interiors, sprawling gardens, and a majestic ballroom, all reflecting the grandeur of the British Raj.

ops.insert: Former royal palace built in 1861, now a gallery displaying paintings, carvings & other artifacts.
Indo-Saracenic palace, completed in 1912, with a grand durbar hall and weekly illuminations.
A large collection of miniaturized bonsai trees, palm trees & rare medicinal herbs fill this garden.
Mansion on University of Mysore campus, now a regional-history museum displaying artifacts & crafts.

Mysore (or Mysuru), a city in India's southwestern Karnataka state, was the capital of the Kingdom of Mysore from 1399 to 1947. In its center is opulent Mysore Palace, seat of the former ruling Wodeyar dynasty. The palace blends Hindu, Islamic, Gothic and Rajput styles. Mysore is also home to the centuries-old Devaraja Market, filled with spices, silk and sandalwood.
Indo-Saracenic palace, completed in 1912, with a grand durbar hall and weekly illuminations.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Mysuru, a city steeped in royal history, is home to some of the most stunning castles and palaces in India. The grandeur of the Mysore Palace, with its intricate architecture and vibrant interiors, captures the essence of the Wodeyar dynasty's opulence. As you stroll through the city, you'll discover not only this iconic landmark but also a treasure trove of lesser-known gems like the Jayalakshmi Vilas Mansion and the enchanting Lalitha Mahal, each telling its own unique story of the past.

Exploring these magnificent structures offers a glimpse into the rich cultural heritage of Mysuru. From the sprawling grounds of the Mysore Zoo to the serene beauty of the Kishkindha Moolika Bonsai Garden, there's a perfect blend of history and nature waiting to be uncovered. Whether you're an architecture enthusiast or simply looking to soak in the royal charm, Mysuru's castles promise an unforgettable journey. So, pack your bags and get ready to explore the regal side of this captivating city!

sources.snippet: Nothing can ever compare to the regal Mysore Palace, but there are many other royal buildings that have played an important part in history. Chief among them is the Jaganmohan Palace, a three-storeyed building, which hou...
sources.shortName: Historical Places In Mysore | Mysore historical places

sources.snippet: Built as a temporary residence for the royal family of Mysore when the Old palace succumbed to fire during the 1896 Dasara festivities, the Jaganmohan palace now functions as a museum and a function hall. The place is built in traditional Hindu architectural style, with carvings of religious motifs and miniature temples, and has three storeys. It houses over 2000 paintings of different schools of art.
sources.shortName: Places to visit in Mysore for the Travelling Architect

sources.snippet: Once famous as a home to the kings of Mysore, Jaganmohan Palace Art Gallery and Auditorium is housed within the Jaganmohan Palace which was established in 1861. It is one of the seven palaces in the city. Regarded as one of the most impeccable contributions of Wodeyar Kings, the palace, one of the most important Mysore tourist places, is now an art gallery as well as a function hall.
sources.shortName: 35 Places to Visit in Mysore, Tourist Places & Top Attractions

sources.snippet: My school was just behind one of the oldest buildings in Mysore‚Ä¶Jaganmohan Palace. Everyday I used to walk to school and back along with friends on the road beside it or we used to take a short cut by walking inside the huge compound and treat ourselves with Joy ice creams sold in one of the stalls and come out on the other side through a small gate that we had discovered.
sources.shortName: Heritage buildings of Mysore - Buildings of a bygone era

sources.snippet: Nothing compares to the majestic Mysore Palace, but there are other more royal structures that have played significant roles in history. The Jaganmohan Palace is a splendid palace that adds to the regal magnificence of this city of palaces, Mysore. This palace is not only a perfect example of architectural brilliance, but it also has a lot of historical significance.

sources.snippet: Situated in the majestic city of Mysore, the Jaganmohan Palace is a spectacular edifice that has an illustrious history attached to its name. Built in the year 1869, it was used by the Wodeyars (Read More) of Mysore when their main residence Amba Vilas Palace was under renovations post a fire accident.

sources.snippet: The beautiful Jaganmohan Palace is located in the centre of Mysuru city. Maharaja Krishnaraja Wodeyar III had it built in 1869. The royal family moved in and lived here when the main palace, Amba Vilas, was under construction after it burnt down in an accident.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Jaganmohan Palace, also known as the Sri Jayachamarajendra Art Gallery, is a historic site located near Mysore City Bus Stand. Originally built in 1861 as a royal retreat, it now houses an impressive art gallery featuring paintings, carvings, and other artifacts. The palace showcases a diverse collection of artworks including paintings by renowned artists like Raja Ravi Varma and Col. Scot, depicting scenes from Hindu epics and historical conflicts.
placeMetadata.address: 8J4X+QW5, Jagan Mohan Palace Road, Subbarayanakere, Chamrajpura, Mysuru, Karnataka 570004, India

reviews.reviewText:
Jagmohan Palace is a true gem of Mysore! The architecture is stunning, showcasing intricate designs and a glimpse of royal heritage. The art gallery inside is a treasure trove for history and art enthusiasts, with an impressive collection of paintings, artifacts, and cultural exhibits. The maintenance of the palace is commendable, and the serene ambiance adds to the experience.

A must-visit for anyone exploring Mysore, whether you're into art, history, or simply admire beautiful architecture. Parking is convenient, and the staff is friendly and helpful. Highly recommended for tourists and locals alike!
Hidden gem of mysore, not a popular place visited by tourist. But must visit if you are art enthusiast. You can see Ravi varma originals here. üòç

If you are an art enthusiast, have 1-2 hours to peacefully stand and stare at the art pieces wondering at their beauty and reading about them, then this definitely is a perfect place for you. Kids might not find it very interesting as it is a collection of paintings and other art collections.
Needs a little more maintenance because the floors are squeaky and rooms are dusty. Some of the paintings are getting ruined and it's very disheartening.

Otherwise it's a very beautiful place !

Visiting the Jaganmohan Palace in Mysuru offers a captivating blend of royal heritage and artistic brilliance. Originally constructed in 1861 by Maharaja Krishnaraja Wodeyar III, this palace served as the royal residence during the reconstruction of the Mysore Palace after a fire. Today, it houses the Sri Jayachamarajendra Art Gallery, showcasing an extensive collection of over 2,000 artworks.

private palace of mysuru dynasty..now converted to art gallery ...it's all about private collection of the kings ..the top floor showcases the love of mummadi krishnaraja wadiyar for dice games with whole room walls filled with various dice games paintings

Shri Jayachamarajendra Art Gallery, housed in the magnificent Jaganmohan Palace, is a must-visit for art and history lovers in Mysore. The gallery features a rich collection of paintings, artifacts, and royal memorabilia, including works by Raja Ravi Varma and other renowned artists. The blend of traditional and modern art gives visitors a deep appreciation for India's artistic heritage.

A must visit art gallery in the close vicinity of mysore palace and stored many historical artefacts original and replicated paintings awesome photographs etc. the main old building area is well curated and display is excellent. But the new attached portion is little ill maintained. You can visit this place just to see the one magical painting the lady with the lamp. Ticket price will be worth by that one painting itself.

A hidden gem for art and history lovers! The palace houses an incredible collection of paintings, including works by Raja Ravi Varma. Peaceful, well-maintained, and full of cultural charm. Perfect for a quiet, enriching visit.

placeMetadata.name: Mysuru Palace

sources.snippet: Much of the tourist interest can be explained by the impressive Mysore Palace, commissioned in 1897, the same year as the terrible plague outbreak, and finished in 1912. There had been several palaces, built and destroyed, since the 14th century; the construction prior to the current building was ruined by fire. The various palaces were for many centuries the official home of the Wodeyars, the Maharajas of the Mysore Kingdom.
sources.shortName: Mysore Palace: India's Most Beautiful Building?

sources.snippet: The Mysore Palace is a majestic structure located in Mysore, Karnataka, and is an exceptionally breathtaking example of Indo-Saracenic style of architecture. The former palace of the royal family of Mysore, also known as the Amba Vilas Palace, is still their formal residence. The great palace, which stands towering in the centre of Mysore city and attracts visitors from all over the world, is a popular tourist destination.
sources.shortName: Popular Royal Buildings And Sites In Mysore

sources.snippet: The city‚Äôs proudest possession and most iconic landmark is the magnificent Mysore Palace. Home of the erstwhile rulers of Mysore, it is now among the famous tourist attractions in India that attracts over 6 million tourists every year. Originally built in the fifth century, this palace has since been demolished and reconstructed and renovated several times.
sources.shortName: 7 Palaces In Mysore You Must Visit

sources.snippet: An incredibly breathtaking example of Indo - Saracenic style of architecture, the Mysore Palace is a magnificent edifice located in Mysore in the state of Karnataka. Also known as the Amba Vila (Read More)s Palace, it is the former palace of the royal family of Mysore and is still their official residence. Referred to as the 'City of Palaces',
sources.shortName: 12 Historical Places in Mysore for a Peek into the Past

sources.snippet: Designed by Henry Irwin, the Mysore Palace is one of the finest achievements of Indo-Saracenic architecture, summing up many diverse themes that have played through Indian architecture over the centuries. Muslim designs and Rajput style combine with Gothic elements and indigenous materials in an exuberant display of grandeur.

placeMetadata.description: Indo-Saracenic palace, completed in 1912, with a grand durbar hall and weekly illuminations.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Mysore Palace, a stunning Indo-Saracenic architectural marvel completed in 1912, boasts a grand durbar hall and hosts weekly illuminations. The palace is famous for the traditional Dasara procession, Jamboo Savari, featuring a decorated elephant carrying the idol of Goddess Chamundeshwari during Vijaya Dashami. This centuries-old celebration was initiated by Raja Wodeyar in 1610 and has continued uninterrupted.
