reviews.reviewText: The Mysore Palace is a true architectural wonder. The intricate carvings, beautiful domes, and royal interiors are a feast for the eyes. I was amazed by how grand and majestic the entire place felt. The evening light show made it even more magical. It's a must-visit place if you're in Karnataka. Highly recommended for history lovers and architecture enthusiasts!

Place is good and Maintained. We went during public holiday so it was so much crowded and we didn't get to see inside of the palace properly. The ticket cost is around 120 Rupees which I didn't think it was worth it as there was no crowd management. But overall good visit and good experience.

Palace is very beautiful ‚ù§Ô∏è

Pros
1. Rich mix of culture and history.
2. Huge campus so it doesn't get crowded.
3. Very well maintained.

Cons
1. Tickets for the Palace is separate from the Light and Sound show.
2. To buy the tickets for the light and aound show you'll have to come outside of the palace again and get in a queue for the tickets.

My visit to Mysore Palace was an incredible experience. This magnificent landmark is a perfect destination for a day trip with family or friends. The palace is absolutely stunning, with a massive structure and intricate architecture that truly make it a highlight of Mysore.
Be prepared for some walking as you explore the beautifully maintained grounds. It's well worth it to take in the details of the palace from every angle. It's also a fantastic place for photography‚Äîthe majestic exteriors and richly decorated interiors provide countless opportunities for amazing photos, whether you're taking portraits or just capturing candid moments.
Within the palace complex, you'll also find a few temples, which add a peaceful and cultural touch to the visit. Overall, it's a memorable place that I highly recommend.

One of the most beautiful palaces in the country that is still being maintained to the best of its heritage, culture, history and the timeless stories that it narrates to all the visitors. Located in the heart of Mysore city, the palace has been holding its charm ever since it was constructed decades ago. Each section of the palace speaks out its legacy of the royal family and their importance in the Mysore dynasty and the Bangalore history. A lot of the palace area is restricted for visitors but the area accessible by the visitors make you drop your jaw while you endure its legacy. It‚Äôs beautiful, architecture is outstanding and the beautifully restored walls. I‚Äôd highly recommend anyone visiting Bangalore of Mysore to visit this place, you‚Äôd not regret your time. The entry ticket is ‚Çπ120 per person and there‚Äôs ample parking space outside. There‚Äôs also toilets after the entry and some food outlets as well. A lot of street vendors outside the palace are selling souvenirs, snacks and everything that you might need for a quick bite.

Only saw it from outside courtyard. Very beautiful from outside, more so in the evening when the entire palace is lit up. Plan to see it from inside next time. Horse cart ride is highly recommended, the long round covers the route around the beautifully lit up palace in the evening covering all 5 palace gates.

Mysore Palace is stunning! The architecture, intricate carvings, and royal interiors are breathtaking. The evening illumination is magical, and the Dussehra celebrations make it even more special. A must-visit to experience the city‚Äôs rich heritage.

Beautiful Palace and with lights on it's even more gorgeous. There are many temples inside and outside all around the palace. The light show happens daily from 7 to 8pm and it is free to enter and see no ticket. You may have to pay for parking though. There are many shops all around to buy eatables and toys and other things like crafts, collectables, etc. It is nice good for taking a walk near a scenic and beautiful place.

reviews.reviewText:
A beautiful heritage building of Mysore University.
The administrative office of the university and Vice Chancellor's office is located in this building..

Standing amidst sprawling grounds, Crawford Hall is now better known as the Mysore University Vice Chancellor‚Äôs office. The majestic vintage 1947 building has imposing Corinthian columns, intricate mouldings and a large picture of Goddess Saraswati in plaster relief (the goddess of learning), which is an apt setting for an office associated with education. It is flanked at two levels by balustrades and pierced parapets in addition to twin Tuscan columns and Roman arches. The building‚Äôs majesty stems partly from the rolling grounds in front and wide approach roads. The building was donated to the university by the Mysore maharaja.

The academic works that is works regarding certificates, marks and marks card is being done in th Crawford hall. The building is an integral part of University of Mysore. There is a canteen inside. A photoshop shop, sbi bank, postal service are also available. Parking is available. There is a garden infront of the hall. The hall is well furnished. The hall has a beautiful chandelier. The buildings are old but they are majestic and royal

Built between 1933-1941, it was inspired by the Cologne Cathedral in Germany. reviews.reviewText:
A Majestic Masterpiece of Faith and Architecture

St. Philomena's Cathedral is absolutely breathtaking. From the moment you step onto the grounds, you're greeted with towering spires and stunning neo-gothic architecture that rivals some of the finest cathedrals in Europe. The stained glass windows, especially the ones depicting scenes from the life of Christ, are nothing short of mesmerizing when sunlight streams through them.

Inside, the atmosphere is peaceful and reverent‚Äîperfect for prayer, reflection, or simply soaking in the beauty. The craftsmanship in every detail, from the altars to the ceiling arches, shows deep devotion and incredible artistry.

Whether you're religious or simply a lover of history and architecture, this cathedral is a must-visit. A true gem of Mysuru that leaves a lasting impression.

---

Want a shorter version or one with a more personal tone?

A peaceful and beautiful church with stunning architecture. The calm atmosphere makes it perfect for prayer and reflection. The stained glass windows and intricate design add to its charm. A must-visit for anyone seeking serenity and history in one place.

This beautiful Cathedral was built in 1956 and is one of the largest churches in the country. It has been built in the Gothic style with beautiful stain glass windows and lofty towers. The illuminated church in the evening is a wonderful site not to be missed.

The church's Gothic-style architecture, with its towering spires, stunning stained-glass windows, and intricate carvings, is a sight to behold. The serene atmosphere and peaceful ambiance make it an ideal spot for prayer, reflection, and contemplation.

The moment you step inside, the high ceilings and beautifully crafted interiors transport you to a different era. The altar, the sculptures, and the detailed carvings showcase the craftsmanship that went into building this historical church. The stained-glass windows depicting scenes from Christ‚Äôs life add to the spiritual charm.

It‚Äôs close to mysore palace 2.5km away and adjacent to muslim moholla. Absolute beauty to visit with friends or family and a must not place to miss during your next trip to Mysore.

St. Philomena‚Äôs Church in Mysore stands as one of the most remarkable examples of Neo-Gothic architecture in India. Built in 1936, its soaring twin spires, visible from afar, make it an iconic landmark of the city. The church interior is equally captivating, with impressive stained-glass panels depicting scenes from the life of Christ, creating a serene and contemplative atmosphere.

The church premises are well maintained, offering visitors both a spiritual retreat and a glimpse into Mysore‚Äôs rich heritage. It is not only a place of worship but also a cultural attraction that draws people from around the world. For anyone exploring Mysore, St. Philomena‚Äôs Church is an essential stop that beautifully blends history, architecture, and devotion.

What a beautiful architecture this building has! it is really pretty and they allow tourists also to take photos and videos. The prayers happen every two hours but outside it's always open. Good view, a must visit if in Mysore.

St. Philomena‚Äôs Church in Mysore is truly breathtaking. From the outside, its majestic neo-Gothic architecture rises proudly toward the sky, leaving visitors in awe. What I found especially fascinating is that the church looks much larger from the outside than it feels on the inside ‚Äì the interior seems almost small and humble in comparison, yet this adds to its charm and intimacy. The church is spotless, well maintained, and offers a peaceful space for rest, reflection, and prayer. A visit to Mysore would not be complete without experiencing this beautiful and imposing landmark.
A great architectural brilliance can be seen. What a massive structure with such good atmosphere. People, the ambience, you will feel yeah a holy place to keep our heart at.

St. Philomena's Cathedral is a Catholic church of Mysore Diocese of India, located Ashok road near Mysore Palace. It was constructed in 1936 with a Neo Gothic style, honour to the memory of Saint Philomena. It's architecture was inspired by the beautiful Cologne Cathedral in Germany. It is one of the tallest church in Asia. The twins spires raising 175 feet are inspiring and the stained glass windows, lofty towers and a marble altar. The outside of the church looks grand, and inside feel spiritual. The serene interior offers a peaceful atmosphere for reflections. It welcomes visitors of all religion and the most important thing is you need to maintain silence. The church is open from 5 am to 6 pm and you can attend mass at the church, which held in Kannada, Tamil and English. It's a very divine place just stand inside the prayer hall, and feel the waves of peace flowing in to your soul.

The parking is quite difficult.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Oriental Research Institute in Mysore is a unique historical attraction that houses one of India's oldest libraries. Established in 1891 by Maharaja Sri Chamaraja Wadeyar, it is now an integral part of Mysore University. The institute boasts around 50,000 rare palm leaf manuscripts from South India, including ancient Sanskrit and Kannada texts. Visitors can explore the collection of ancient literature and stone edicts while witnessing the regular restoration of palm leaves.
placeMetadata.address: University of Mysore, Kautilya Circle near, near Crawford Hall, Mysuru, Karnataka 570005, India

reviews.reviewText: A place of knowledge where you can find ancient wisdom written on palm leaves. You can see more than 14 thousand palm leaf manuscripts which contains 70 thousand works of different authors.

When Scholars felt the need to collect, and preserve Sanskrit and Kannada palm leaf and Manuscripts, the idea of establishing an institution in the name of ‚ÄòOriental Library‚Äô came in their mind and that resulted in its establishment by Maharaja Sri Chamaraja Wadeyar in 1891. Mysore University was started in 1916. Since then ‚ÄòOriental Library‚Äô became an integral part of Mysore University. Its objects are to collect, preserve, edit and publish the rare valuable Sanskrit and Kannada palm leaf as well as Paper Manuscripts available in our country. Later in 1943 ‚ÄòOriental Library‚Äô was renamed as ‚ÄòOriental Research Institute‚Äô.
It is managed and administered by Director and staff. It has compiled and published ‚ÄòSritattvanidhi‚Äô of Sri Mummadi Krishnaraja Wadeyar, in three Volumes, comprising of Shakthi Nidhi, Vishnu Nidhi and Shiva Nidhi, apart from many other rare Sanskrit works. It has to its credit vast number of collection exceeding a lakh. Its library, as I have seen, contains more than 50,000 books in Sanskrit, Kannada, English, Hindi and other languages. It is an internationally recognised institution getting financial aid from USA and others.
Infact Oriental Library was the first public library in Mysore that was dedicated to the cause of research and editing of manuscripts, keeping Indology as its prime focus. It has published nearly 200 titles from 1893 till date. It has preserved in its womb a rich collection of more than 75000 ancient, rare and highly valued materials, books and documents. I can quote some important and rare collections like Encyclopaedia of Religion and Ethics by James Hastings, Vedic Concordance by Maurice Bloomfield and critical editions of Ramayana and Mahabharata. I could not find any difficulty to pick the book of choice because the books are systematically arranged to have easy access to reader‚Äôs desired books and documents.
The palm leaves manuscripts are of standard size of 15cm x 3.5cm. These are extraordinary manuscripts that open an unusual window to literature, philosophy, astrology, religious practices and languages that were in vogue in primordial times. Manuscripts are organic materials at risk of decay and destruction by Silverfish. Lemon grass oil is applied on manuscripts to preserve them. Lemon grass oil actually injects natural fluidity into the brittle palm leaves and hydrophobic nature of oil keeps the manuscripts dry and the text is not lost due to humidity. Conventional method is adopted to preserve manuscripts in microfilm. Original manuscripts are available for reference. ‚ÄòThe Emperor's Riddles‚Äô authored by Satyarth Nayak was featured by it in 2014. It is a mystery thriller novel as I have seen. I have visited this library several times.
Oriental Institute is a treasure trove for knowledge seekers and research students and scholars, having preserved several greatest works of literature, philosophy, religion and what not! Visitors are allowed to see the palm leaf and paper manuscripts. It has preserved not only the rare manuscripts safely but also makes them available for research purposes. The name itself suggests its commitments to propagate Indian culture and heritage. It has been encouraging and furthering Indological research all these years from its inception. It is in reality a museum displaying 50,000 ancient palm-leaf manuscripts and later manuscripts in paper.
Oriental Institute is found at northern end of Krishnaraja Boulevard Road. It is adjacently opposite to Crawford Hall and within the campus of Mysore University. Its building is architecturally beautiful and attracts viewers from a distance. It is actually the Jubilee Hall built in 1887 to commemorate golden jubilee of Queen Victoria`s taking over British throne.
It is kept open for public from 8am to 8pm on all days. Contact on 0821 ‚Äì 2420331/2419336.

reviews.reviewText:
captures the essence of Mysore's local culture. It's a bustling marketplace filled with fresh fruits, vegetables, flowers, spices, and traditional items. The fragrance of jasmine and incense sticks, combined with the vivid colors of fruits and flowers, creates an unforgettable sensory experience.

The market is well-organized, and the vendors are friendly, often engaging visitors with stories about their products. It's a great place to buy souvenirs like sandalwood products and Mysore silk at reasonable prices.

While it can get crowded, that's part of its charm.

stepping into Devaraja Market in Mysore is like entering a completely different world ‚Äì a vibrant, sensory overload in the best possible way! It's not your typical sterile shopping experience; it's raw, it's bustling, and it's full of life.
The first thing that hits you is the explosion of colors and smells. Piles upon piles of bright fruits and vegetables are everywhere ‚Äì the deep red of tomatoes, the vibrant yellow of bananas, the lush green of leafy vegetables. And the fragrance? A mix of sweet flowers, earthy spices, and fresh produce all mingling together. It‚Äôs quite intoxicating!
What I loved is how authentic it feels. You see local vendors, many of whom have been there for generations, passionately selling their goods. There's a real buzz of interaction between them and the customers, a friendly banter that you don't often find in modern supermarkets.
You can find pretty much anything here, from fresh produce and flowers (oh, the marigolds and jasmine are just gorgeous!) to spices, incense, and even some household items. It‚Äôs a feast for the senses at every turn.
Navigating through the narrow pathways can be a bit chaotic, with people and handcarts moving around, but that's part of its charm. It feels like you're right in the heart of the city's everyday life.
I spent a good amount of time just wandering around, taking it all in. I bought some fragrant spices and a few local fruits that I hadn't tried before. It felt good to support the local economy directly.
It's not a fancy, air-conditioned mall; it's a traditional market, and it has all the character that comes with that. If you want to experience the real pulse of Mysore and soak in the local culture, Devaraja Market is a must-visit. Just be prepared for the crowds and the sensory overload ‚Äì embrace it, and you'll have a fantastic time!
In a human way:
* It's a vibrant and bustling market with an explosion of colors and smells.
* You can find a wide variety of fresh produce, flowers, and spices.
* It feels very authentic, with local vendors and lively interactions.
* It's a great place to experience the local culture and support the community.
* Be prepared for crowds and a sensory-rich environment.
If you're looking for an authentic and lively experience in Mysore, Devaraja Market is definitely worth exploring. It's a sensory adventure!

Mysore Market, also known as Devaraja Market, is one of the oldest and most iconic marketplaces in Karnataka. Located in the center of Mysore city, it‚Äôs not just a shopping destination‚Äîit‚Äôs a cultural experience in itself. Walking through the market feels like stepping into a different world, where tradition and daily life blend seamlessly.

The first thing you‚Äôll notice is the explosion of colors‚Äîbright orange marigolds, red chilies, green herbs, and vibrant pigments used for religious and decorative purposes. The air is filled with the scent of fresh flowers, spices, and incense, creating a sensory experience that‚Äôs truly unforgettable. Stalls are lined with fresh produce, aromatic oils, sandalwood products, and handmade items that reflect the craftsmanship of local artisans.

The market is well-organized, with separate sections for fruits and vegetables, flowers, puja items, and household goods. It‚Äôs a great place to interact with locals, many of whom are eager to share stories or explain the use of their products. The vendors are generally friendly and open to bargaining, making it a fun place to shop.

What sets Mysore Market apart is its authenticity. Unlike commercial malls, it offers a raw and genuine glimpse into the daily life of Mysore‚Äôs residents. It‚Äôs also a photographer‚Äôs dream, filled with colorful scenes and lively characters.

Whether you're a traveler, a photographer, a foodie, or just curious, Mysore Market is a must-visit. It‚Äôs more than a place to shop‚Äîit's a place to connect with Mysore‚Äôs soul.

reviews.reviewText:
The Mysore City Corporation (MCC) is the administrative body responsible for civic amenities and some infrastructural assets of the Mysore City area. It is the third largest Municipal Corporation in Karnataka being responsible for a population of 1 million in an area of 235 km. Its boundaries have expanded more than 2 times over the last decade.

Its roles and responsibilities include the "orderly development of the city" ‚Äî zoning and building regulations, health, hygiene, licensing, trade and education, as well as quality of life issues such as public open space, water bodies, parks and greenery.

The MCC represents the third level of government (the Central Government and State Government being the first two levels). MCC is run by a city council composed of elected representatives, called "corporators", one from each of the wards (localities) of the city.

sources.snippet: The Cheluvamba Mansion on the Mysore-Krishnaraja Sagar road is in the northwest part of the city. The palace, which is near Mysore Railway Station, was built in 1911 for Princess Cheluvajammanni, the third daughter of Maharaja Krishnaraja Wodeyar IV. Like the other buildings of the Wadiyar dynasty, the building is spread over a large area and surrounded by beautifully landscaped gardens. Currently, it is home to the Central Food Technological Research Institute.

The walking path is well-maintained, and benches are available along the way to sit and take in the view. Kukkarahalli Lake in Mysuru is a serene and scenic destination, perfect for nature lovers, joggers, and birdwatchers alike. Nestled within the heart of the city, the lake offers a peaceful 4.5 km walking trail surrounded by lush greenery, making it an ideal spot for early morning walks or relaxing evening strolls. Visitors often praise the area for its cleanliness, cool shade from trees, and abundance of birds‚Äîespecially during migratory seasons. The lake is home to species like pelicans, storks, and kingfishers, attracting photographers and wildlife enthusiasts. Though boating has been discontinued, the charm of the lake remains intact, with quiet corners to sit, reflect, or write. Some minor concerns include occasional water quality issues and a lack of public restrooms. Despite this, Kukkarahalli Lake continues to be a beloved urban escape, celebrated not only for its ecological beauty but also its cultural heritage, having inspired many local writers and poets. Entry is free, and the lake is easily accessible from key areas of Mysore.

It features colourful foliage and lawns, as well as a separate play area for kids, making it an ideal spot to spend a pleasant afternoon or evening.
placeMetadata.address: 8J3W+4CW, Chamaraja Double Road, Subbarayanakere, Chamrajpura, Mysuru, Karnataka 570004, India

reviews.reviewText:
At a distance of 2 km from Mysore Railway Station, Freedom Fighter's Park is a public park located in the Chamrajapura locality of Mysore, Karnataka. Also known as Subbarayanakere Park, it is one of the places to visit in Mysore.

Freedom Fighter's Park was built to commemorate the 'Mysore Chalo' movement, one of the most significant events in the history of Mysuru which resulted in the establishment of a democratic government in Mysore. Freedom fighters assembled at this very spot, launching a resistance movement when the Maharaja of Mysore retained the rule of the state. As a part of the protest, the Indian flag was hoisted every day at this park by freedom fighters, which eventually made the Maharaja surrender to the demand for democracy in 1947.

It is a huge park known for its unmatched beauty, lush green lawns, and bright flower beds. The major attractions of the park are the captivating and magnificent statues of the freedom fighters including Mahatma Gandhi. The park also has a separate play area for kids and space for yoga, meditation, etc. Revisit the scenes of India's struggle to become a democracy amidst nature's beauty at this park as part of Mysore tour packages.

placeMetadata.name: Cheluvamba Hospital

sources.snippet: K.R.Hospital as it is popularly known was constructed at a cost of three and a half lakhs with 100 beds and Cheluvamba hospital known as Vanivilas Hospital was built in 1880 with 24 beds. This hospital is one of the oldest hospitals in the country and the architecture bears similar stamps of all the other heritage buildings in the city. Nalwadi Krishnaraja Wodeyar founded the Mysore Medical College in 1924 and this was the first in the Karnataka region and the seventh in India.

Chamundeshwari Temple ‚Äì Divine Views & Deep Peace üõïüåÑ

My visit to Chamundeshwari Temple was a truly serene and spiritual experience. Located atop the Chamundi Hills, the journey itself felt sacred ‚Äî with breathtaking views of Mysore city unfolding along the way.

The temple, dedicated to Goddess Chamundeshwari, is rich in history, power, and devotion. The divine presence can truly be felt the moment you enter. The architecture is beautiful, the surroundings peaceful, and the energy‚Äîunmatched.

Climbing the famous 1,000 steps or simply driving up gives a sense of devotion and calm. The darshan was smooth, and the view from the top was absolutely worth the visit ‚Äî especially during sunrise or sunset!

It‚Äôs more than just a temple; it‚Äôs a place to pause, reflect, and reconnect. A must-visit when you‚Äôre in Mysore for spiritual seekers and peace lovers alike. üôèüå∏

The Chamundeshwari Temple is one of the most sacred and iconic temples in Mysore, situated on the Chamundi Hills. The temple is dedicated to Goddess Chamundeshwari, the presiding deity of Mysore. The atmosphere here is very peaceful and spiritual, with a beautiful view of the entire Mysore city from the hilltop.

‚ú® Highlights:

The temple‚Äôs architecture is stunning with its tall, intricately carved gopuram.

Well-maintained premises and a strong spiritual vibe.

Panoramic view of Mysore Palace and the city lights from the hill.

Free shoe-stand and drinking water facility available.

‚è∞ Best Time to Visit: Early morning or evening to avoid crowds and enjoy pleasant weather.
üöó Accessibility: You can reach the temple by car, bus, or even by climbing the 1,000+ steps for a divine experience.

This is my go-to temple for its peaceful vibes and the incredible experience it offers. The ride up the ghat road, especially on a bike, is thrilling and scenic. From the hilltop, you get a breathtaking panoramic view of the entire Mysore city.

Though it tends to get crowded, the wait is absolutely worth it. The area also features a large number of shopping stalls, adding to the lively atmosphere.

Visited the famous Chamundeshwari Temple in Mysore‚Äîan important spiritual landmark.
The temple sits atop Chamundi Hill and offers a divine, peaceful atmosphere.
However, it was extremely crowded during our visit, and we had to wait a long time in line.
The queue was quite long, especially near the darshan area, but it moved steadily.
Despite the rush, the temple staff managed the crowd fairly well.
The view from the top of the hill was stunning, with a clear view of Mysore city.
The temple architecture is beautiful, rich with history and carvings.
Devotees were patient, and the overall vibe remained calm and spiritual.
Shops around the temple sell prasad, souvenirs, and snacks‚Äîadds to the experience.
Parking can be a challenge during weekends or holidays due to the rush.
I recommend visiting early in the morning or on weekdays for a smoother experience.
Still, the darshan was peaceful and spiritually fulfilling once we reached inside.
It‚Äôs a must-visit place if you‚Äôre exploring Mysore‚Äîspiritually and culturally rich.
The hilltop breeze and scenic drive up add to the experience

"Visited the Chamundeshwari Temple in Mysore and was mesmerized by its grandeur and spiritual aura. Perched atop Chamundi Hills, the temple offers breathtaking views of the city below. The intricate architecture and vibrant decorations make it a must-visit for devotees and tourists alike. The majestic Nandi statue at the foothills is equally impressive, symbolizing devotion and strength. The temple's history and mythology are palpable, and the serene atmosphere provides a perfect setting for reflection. A truly enriching experience that showcases the rich cultural heritage of Karnataka."

This temple is a must-visit if you‚Äôre in Mysore ‚Äî not just for the spiritual aura, but also for the breathtaking city views on the way up. The roads are wide and smooth, making the drive or ride genuinely enjoyable.

Heads up on footwear storage:

Some shops near the parking will try to tell you there‚Äôs no shoe storage at the top ‚Äî don‚Äôt believe them. It‚Äôs just a way to get you to buy pooja items so they can ‚Äúwatch‚Äù your footwear.

Truth is, there‚Äôs proper footwear storage available right near the temple entrance, with a ‚Çπ5 token system ‚Äî safe, easy, and no pressure to buy anything.

Entry options:

1. ‚Çπ100 ‚Äì Front gate (quickest)

2. ‚Çπ30 ‚Äì Side entry (bit of a line but manageable)

They do not accept online payments, so carry cash.

Also, you‚Äôll find washrooms and a few refreshment stalls nearby in case you need a quick bite or drink post-darshan.

The scenery on the top is amazing. You can see the whole Mysore from the top. We were fortunate enough to witness the amazing weather which marked the monsoon for now. And as it was a weekend the rush was little more but for sure a must visit place if you are planning for Mysore.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Maharaja's College, part of the University of Mysore, is a historic institution that has been a beacon of education since its inception. Nestled in the heart of Mysuru, it offers a rich tapestry of academic programs and cultural experiences. The college is surrounded by iconic landmarks such as the Clock Tower and Jaganmohan Palace, making it an integral part of the city's heritage. Students often share their transformative journeys here; for instance, one alumna recalls her time studying B.A.

reviews.reviewText: Maharaja‚Äôs college by university is a great boys college which offers under graduate and post graduate courses. It was one of reputated boys college in Mysore. So many great philosophers, writers, well trained professionals graduated from this college.

This college is one of the well known college in Mysore,, mainly this college famous for LIBRAR and its heritage Infrastructure.All  lecturers are good , specially English Dept.
But college maintenance is not good (specially exam section)and this college not have good washrooms. There is response to ur complaints..

Maharaja PU college is boys college and it's one of the oldest college in Mysore and lots of great personality are studied here and the college building is also a one of the heritage building ,it has a great environment inside and outside with playing ground and parking lot and it is situated in the heart of the city and also the women's college maharani's college is present opposite direction to it
College is super . Ba Bba Commerce corces available. But . Most students are boys

I studied B A (History, Economics, English Literature) here during 2001-2004. I was advised by Dr M B Padma, then  principal not to take English Literature as major, instead would study Kannada major so that I could achieve great. The reason she had pointed out that I had studied in Kannada medium. She also said that you are eligible to get English according to the ranking list (17th Rank). Then I didn't know much about the career and courses difficulty. Now I feel that I would have studied Kannada Literature and would have achieved better career success. Currently, Iam lecturer in Teacher Training Institute in Bengaluru.

Fortunate to have had such a greater care and concern she took. We were blessed to have eminent professors, HoDs and Principal. To name a few Prof C Naganna, P N Sridevi, Latha K Biddappa, Anitha V Braggs, Bhagavan, R Keshav, B Ramachandrappa, Cha Sarvamangala and so on. The kind of alround development we could experience was so great. I was also did NCC.

I had a rural background and my parents were poor. I had to work part-time from 3:30pm to 12 midnight every day for my books and fees, meals.

Mysore (or Mysuru), a city in India's southwestern Karnataka state, was the capital of the Kingdom of Mysore from 1399 to 1947. In its center is opulent Mysore Palace, seat of the former ruling Wodeyar dynasty. The palace blends Hindu, Islamic, Gothic and Rajput styles. Mysore is also home to the centuries-old Devaraja Market, filled with spices, silk and sandalwood.
Set on top of a hill, this historic Hindu temple is open to the public & offers panoramic vistas.
Artificial lake created in 1864, surrounded by an unpaved, 4.5km walking path with stone benches.
Now a museum, this former armory dating to the early 20th century displays guns & cannons.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Mysuru, a city steeped in history and culture, is not just famous for its royal heritage but also for its stunning architecture that reflects a blend of tradition and modernity. From the grandeur of the Mysore Palace, with its intricate Indo-Saracenic design, to the serene beauty of the Jayalakshmi Vilas Mansion, each structure tells a story of the city's rich past and vibrant present. As you stroll through the streets, you'll encounter a variety of architectural styles that showcase the creativity and craftsmanship of local designers, making Mysuru a treasure trove for architecture enthusiasts.

The Wanderlog team is passionate about uncovering the unique architectural gems that Mysuru has to offer. Whether you're admiring the elegant spires of St. Philomena's Cathedral or exploring the innovative designs of contemporary firms like ENNYESK Architects, there's something for everyone in this city. Each building, from the historic to the modern, contributes to the tapestry of Mysuru's architectural landscape. So, grab your camera and get ready to explore the best of Mysuru's architecture, where every corner reveals a new masterpiece waiting to be discovered.
